attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock count was performed on 20March 2025 to confirm the accuracy of inventory records by comparing the actual stock with the system records and to detect any potential losses arising from fraud, damage or incorrect postings.

·       The physical stock balances were consistent with the book balances, except for the following discrepancies:

ü  Bread stock had a variance of -13.75 pieces,

ü  Packing materials had cumulative variance of +1,477 pieces,

ü  Wheat Bran had a variance of +8.61kgs,

ü  Brown Flour +3.61kgs

ü  White flour had -0.2kgs,

ü  Yeast had a variance of -0.19sachet

ü  Vegetable oil had a variance of -4.56kgs

The stock findings are illustrated in the summary below:

Table 1: Stock Take Findings

Implication.

While most of the variances are relatively small, these differences could indicate underlying issues such as inaccurate postings, potential fraud, or operational inefficiencies that could affect inventory management.
attributes.recommendation: Existing inventory controls should be strengthened, with a particular focus on ensuring minimal or nil variances especially in items such as bread stock, yeast, vegetable oil and packing materials

value: We have been able to control stock well and this will be maintained.
The control is in place and effective and thus we shall maintain.

·       In prior audit dated 14th March 2025:

ü  Bread stock had a variation of -8.50 pieces,

ü  Poly bags had a variance of +122 pieces,

ü  Wheat bran variance of +6.75kg,

ü  Brown Flour had a +0.04kg,

ü  White flour had a variance of -0.2kgs,

ü  Yeast had a variance of -0.37sachet

ü  Crates had nil balance.

attributes.title: Bread weights.
attributes.description:
·       A weight check was conducted on the bread produced and packed at the branch to ensure compliance with the KEBS standard weight for all bread types distributed to the market.

·       From the sample 400g Bw, 200g Ml and 400g Ct varieties had significant underweight percentages, with 200g Ml showing the highest percentage of underweight at 49%.

·        Overweight percentages were relatively low across all varieties with the highest in 600g Bw at 36%.

·       The correct weight percentages varied across the samples, with 800g Bt having the highest percentage of correctly weighted bread at 91%.

·       The table below illustrates the findings:

Table 2 : Weight check analysis.

Implication

·       Failing to comply with weights and measures laws exposes the company to legal penalties, fines, or sanctions from regulatory authorities.

·       Persistent non-compliance could lead to license suspension or revocation, disrupting operations.

Consistent failure to meet weight standards may affect consumer trust and damage the company’s reputation. Customers may perceive the brand as unreliable which can lead to a decline in sales.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should ensure that every step of the bread production process strictly adheres to the required weight standards.

·       The management should also review the existing procedures for measuring and controlling the weight of bread throughout production to ensure compliance with set standards.

value: We will ensure that bread production from the first step adhere to set weights to ensure that the end product is of correct weight.

·       We will ensure correct procedures are followed.

·       To conduct regular spot checks to ensure no more underweight bread

·       In a prior audit report, under weights were mostly observed as follows,

ü  200g-31%,

ü  400g long-89%,

ü  400g-7%,

ü  400g Bw-45%,

ü  600g-7%,

ü  1.5kg-33%

·        Over weights

ü      400g-14%,

ü  600g-49%

ü  800g-8%.

attributes.title: Bread damages analysis
attributes.description:
·       We carried out an assessment of bread damages at the Thika branch between 18 February and 20 March 2025, to evaluate whether the production process followed the established quality control standards. The review was intended to verify compliance with the set damage limits, which are 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       The review revealed that market damages accounted for 0.95% of total sales, which exceeded the allowed limit of 0.50%. Productions damages, on the other hand, were at 0.33% of total production which was above the maximum acceptable limit as detailed below:

    Table 3 :Production Damages analysis

    Table 4 :Market Damages analysis

Findings

·       The assessment revealed that damaged tins, which were identified in the previous audit, continue to cause production issues. These damaged tins negatively affect the quality and appearance of the bread contributing to both high production damages and increased market returns.

Implication

The cost implications for both production and market damages combined amount to (177,571.04), which impacts profitability.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management should prioritize replacing these damaged tins as soon as possible to reduce the defects in bread quality and minimize both production damages and market returns.

The branch management should also strengthen the monitoring process during production to ensure that damaged tins do not continue to affect bread quality

value: The damages are caused by the conditions of our tins but we have plans to replace them and this will help to minimize the amount of damages.

·       This is mainly caused by the condition of baking tins affecting both quality & appearance leading to high production damages & market returns.

We have made official request to replace damaged tins.

·       In a prior audit report dated 14th March 2025 ;

ü  Production damages rate was 0.30 % of total production,

ü  Market damages rate stood at 0.91% of total sales inclusive of supermarket returns.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The objective of this test was to review the mixing chart records, both shift-wise and summarized, for the period between 18 February and 20 March 2025. The primary focus was to evaluate the branch’s Utto oil usage, average yield and any occurrences of remixes as outlined below:

Ø  The Utto consumption was at1 unit per bag implying a ration of bags to utto unit of 1:1

Ø  The average yield for the reviewed period was 191.50 loaves per bag.

Ø  Average production was 100.81 bags per day representing 82.63% of target achievement which is 122 bags as tabled below:

           Table 5: Mixing chart Analysis summary.

Implication

The branch achieved only 82.63% of the daily production target which indicates a shortfall in production efficiency. This underperformance can lead to missed sales opportunities and reduced revenue potential.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The sales team should focus on expanding the customer base to ensure the branch's production capacity is utilized to its fullest potential.

value: We will keep in touch with set parameters concerning production.
To align with production records.

·       Previous audit report dated 14th March 2025 indicated the following:

ü  Yield-191.57,

ü  Utto-1:1~ 100%,

ü  Average Prod. – 93.79.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       As part of our standard procedures, a cash audit was carried out to verify that the actual cash available matched the recorded cash balance in the cash-flow documentation. This review also aimed to assess the effectiveness of the cash management controls in place.

Findings

·       The spot check revealed that cash balances were well-controlled, with a minimal variance of -1, which was attributed to change balances.

Implication

The minimal variance of -1 indicates that cash management controls are largely effective, with only a slight difference due to change balances.
attributes.recommendation: Continue to monitor cash-flow records regularly to ensure consistency between the physical cash on hand and the recorded balances.

value: Emphasise on frequent stocks to ensure control is maintained
The control in place is effective and thus  we shall maintain
·       From prior audit report, cashier had correctly accounted for all cash, as the cash counted matched the cash flow balance.

attributes.title: Minishop Spot Chec
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was carried out at the Mini Shop on 21March 2025 to confirm that all bread intended for sale was accurately recorded and to ensure that the sales figures matched the balances associated with the provided pay bill number as the Mini Shop follows a policy of not accepting physical cash.

·       We noted that all sales recorded up until the time of the spot check were accurately accounted for. Furthermore, the physical stock of bread including all loadings and top-ups (excluding sales) was present as expected.

·       However, there was a discrepancy of KSh 289.50, with the adjusted M-Pesa balance exceeding the expected sales revenue, as detailed below:

Table 8: Minishop spot check summary.

Implication

·        The positive variance of KSh 289.50 indicates that recorded transactions slightly surpassed the expected sales revenue, which could be attributed to customer overpayments.

This variance though minor, signals the need for closer monitoring to prevent any potential discrepancies from accumulating over time.
attributes.recommendation:
·       We recommend conducting regular spot checks to ensure consistent alignment between sales records and M-Pesa balances.

The Mini Shop staff should implement a review mechanism to assess customer overpayments and ensure all transactions are correctly recorded and reconciled.

value: Frequent stock taking to keep the control in check
We will conduct regular spot checks to ensure control remains effective.
In previous audit report, mini shop bread balance was subtracted from the total loadings to determine the daily sales, which matched the confirmed Mpesa till amount.

attributes.title: Debtor Analysis
attributes.description:
·       A review of the debtors' balances as of 21st March 2025 was carried out to identify any instances of outstanding debts or unresolved balances by route.

·        It was observed that the majority of routes had zero balances or prepaid balances, while some routes still had outstanding balances, as shown below 

Implication.

The presence of outstanding balances on several accounts, especially those marked as dormant poses a credit risk to the branch if it remain uncollected for a long time.
attributes.recommendation: The sales team should be instructed to engage with dormant accounts possibly offering payment plans for early settlement to facilitate collection.

value: I will communicate with the sales team and emphasize that debts are recovered.
The unpaid debts are being followed by sales team.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An evaluation of production efficiency was conducted to assess whether workers were achieving their set production targets and to pinpoint areas for improvement by examining workforce utilization, actual versus expected output and the cost impact of any inefficiencies.

·       We observed that the production efficiency per worker was 4.38 bags, which aligns with the established target of 4.3 bags per worker.

·       A summary of the audit findings is illustrated below:

    Table 6: Production Efficiency.

Implication

The production efficiency of 4.38 bags per worker which is slightly above the target of 4.3 bags per worker indicates that the workforce is performing well and meeting production expectations.
attributes.recommendation:
·       If sales remain low, branch management should explore options for better aligning the workforce with actual production needs, such as offering flexible work schedules or temporarily adjusting staffing levels.

Sales representative should focus on driving sales through marketing initiatives or expanding the customer base to avoid further reductions in production.

value: Due to low sales we reduced production to control the bread balances.

·       Low sales have led to us minimizing production in order to minimise wastage.

·       This measure is necessary to prevent losses

We will ensure targets are achieved.

·       In prior audit dated 14th March 2025, it was noted that:

Average production efficiency was 4.37 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The branch's use of human resources in the packaging section was assessed by reviewing packing efficiency specifically the number of crates packed per worker and comparing it to the branch's standard efficiency rate of 97 crates per worker.

Ø  From 18 February to 20 March 2025 the average packing efficiency was 84.27 crates per packer which falls short of the standard target of 97 crates per packer for the sampled period, as detailed in the table below.

   Table 7: Packing efficiency analysis.

Implications

·       The extra 86 packers hired have resulted in unnecessary labour costs without contributing significantly to productivity.

·       The breakdown of the slicing machine has impacted production timelines and contributed to the failure in meeting the packing efficiency target.

The failure to meet the packing target is not only affecting cost control but also impacting overall production flow.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch Management should review the staffing requirements for the packaging section to ensure that the number of packers hired aligns with the actual production needs.

Branch Management to consider conducting regular maintenance checks on critical machines to prevent unexpected breakdowns.

value:
·       We have been experiencing breakdown of our slicing machine and this has contributed to targets not been met.

·       Moving forward packers will be monitored closely to ensure set targets are met

·       This month we experienced machine breakdown but hence forth we will ensure that we archive required targets.

·       We commit to hire workers as per the required standard rates

·       From prior audit dated 14th March 2025 It was noted that;

Average packing efficiency was 84.27 crates per packer

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed and evaluated the fuel consumption rates of the generators for the period from 1 March to 21 March 2025 to assess whether the generators were functioning efficiently and within the expected operational parameters.

·       Upon analysing the data, it was found to be reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this time frame.

·       However, a variance of 51 litres was noted between the System Generator records and the manager’s logbook, as shown in Appendix 2 below:

      Table 9: Generator Fuel Consumption managers book

·       However the audit noted of the following variation between records and the system as shown below;

Implication.

The discrepancy between the manager’s logbook and the system records (a 51-litre variance) raises concerns about the accuracy and reliability of the fuel consumption data.
attributes.recommendation: ·       Branch management should define operational benchmarks for fuel consumption based on the generator's expected performance.

value: I will keep in touch with the fleet control to ensure accuracy
·       The generator fuelling is controlled by fleet management to check with tracking the actual consumption.
In prior audit, it was noted that the actual generator fuel consumption was 2.09ltrs per hour.

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       A review of the mileage records for all branch route vehicles was conducted for the period from 1st February to 28 February 2025.

·       The purpose of this review was to determine if the vehicles' fuel consumption adhered to the set standard rates, ensuring effective resource utilization.

·       It was observed that, overall, the fuel consumption across the fleet is in line with the established standard rates, with the exception of certain vehicles showing discrepancies. Fuel for these vehicles will be recovered, as detailed in below

Implication

The overall fuel consumption for most of the branch route vehicles aligns closely with the established standard rates, indicating efficient resource usage across the fleet. However, a few vehicles displayed minor variances in fuel consumption when compared to the standard rates.
attributes.recommendation: It is recommended to continue monitoring fuel consumption regularly to identify any trends or emerging issues that may require further consideration or adjustment. A more frequent review of vehicles with minor variances can help minimize larger discrepancies in the future.

value: I will strictly issue fuel as per consumption required.
I will closely follow up to get actual fuel consumed
In prior audit, it was noted that the actual fuel consumption for each vehicle was within the set standard with Tuktuk KTWC 668S being under mechanical repair.
